Tailored Co/SBA-15 catalyst for highly efficient hydrodeoxygenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-dimethylfuran Ting Wu Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation Xiang Zhang Investigation Data curation Hongju Liang Investigation Data curation Quan Wang Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Chun-Ling Liu Writing – review & editing Resources Project administration Methodology Funding acquisition ⁎ Wen-Sheng Dong Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Methodology Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU), MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi’an 710062, China Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU), MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University Xi’an 710062 China Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU), MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi’an 710062, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The design of highly efficient and cost-effective catalysts for the conversion of biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) into sustainable liquid fuel 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) is both important and challenging. In this study, we developed a non-noble Co catalyst supported on SBA-15 (25Co/SBA-15). Our results demonstrate that this catalyst exhibits remarkable efficiency in selectively hydrodeoxygenating 5-HMF to DMF, achieving a DMF yield of 96.3 % with complete conversion of 5-HMF under mild reaction conditions (150 °C, 2.0 MPa H2 for 2 h). Notably, the productivity rate of DMF reached an exceptional value of 19.1 mmol·gcat−1·h−1, surpassing most previously reported catalysts in literature. Additionally, by utilizing two distinct solvents - N,N-dimethylformamide (N,N-DMF) resulting in a high yield of 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF) and tetrahydrofuran (THF) yielding an even higher yield of DMF - our approach enables facile switching between these two products during hydrogenation over the Co/SBA-15 catalyst. Furthermore, our catalyst demonstrates excellent reusability and can be easily regenerated through calcination in air. The exceptional catalytic performance of the catalyst can be ascribed to the synergistic effect between metallic Co and adjacent Lewis acidic Co2+ in CoO dispersed on the surface of SBA-15. A dual-site Langmuir–Hinshelwood–Hougen–Watson (LHHW) model was proposed for the hydrodeoxygenating 5-HMF to DMF. Graphical Abstract Keywords 5-hydroxymethylfurfural 2.5-dimethylfuran 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan Co/SBA-15 Hydrodeoxygenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biomass is a sustainable and renewable carbon resource that can serve as an alternative to fossil-based compounds for the production of high-value-added chemicals [1–3]. The one of most important platform compounds derived from biomass, 5-HMF, can be transformed into various essential compounds through esterification, hydrogenolysis, and oxidation processes. Diol monomers such as BHMF, 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl) tetrahydrofuran (BHTHF), and 1,6-hexanediol (HDO) can be synthesized by hydrogenolysis of 5-HMF and hold significant practical value as critical monomers in polyurethane and polyester production [4–7]. Moreover, the hydrodeoxygenation of 5-HMF enables the production of sustainable liquid fuels like DMF [8–10] and 2,5-dimethyltetrahydrofuran (DMTHF) [9]. DMF has been identified as a fuel additive due to its exceptional octane number, high energy density and excellent miscibility with gasoline [10]. Additionally, it serves as a solvent for substances with high boiling points and acts as a precursor in the production of p-xylene and plastics [11–13]. Considerable efforts have been devoted to the development of efficient catalysts for the hydrodeoxygenation of 5-HMF to DMF. To date, a wide range of catalysts based on noble metals such as Ru [14,15], Pd [16–18], Pt [19,20] and Ir [21]; non-noble metals including Co [22,23], Ni [24,25], and Cu [26,27]; as well as bimetallic materials like Ru-Co [28,29], Pt-Co [30], Cu-Co [31,32], Ni-Co [33,34], Co-Fe [35], Cu-Ni [36,37] and Fe-Ni [38] have been extensively investigate. For instance, Zu et al. [39] achieved a DMF yield of 94.1 % with 99 % HMF conversion using a Ru/Co3O4 catalyst (with a catalysts-to-substrate ratio of 40 %) under mild reaction conditions (130 °C and 0.7 MPa H2 pressure) in the presence of THF solvent over a period of 24 h. Zhang et al. [17] reported that Pd/MOF-808 exhibited 99 % yield of DMF at 100 °C and 1.0 MPa H2 within 3 h utilizing a catalyst loading equivalent to ∼53 % of the substrate. Meng et al. [40] presented isolated Pt single atoms supported on the Ni3Fe intermetallic support (Pt1/Ni3Fe IMC), which exhibited 99 % conversion of 5-HMF and 98.1 % yield of DMF in 90 min at 160 °C, employing a catalyst loading corresponding to ∼73.4 % of the substrate. Xiang et al. [41] reported a core-shell structured Co@CoO catalyst exhibiting good activity in the hydrodeoxygenation of HMF to DMF, achieving a DMF yield of 89 % at 130 °C and 1.0 MPa H2 pressure for 2 h with a catalysts-to-substrate ratio of 20 %. Ahishakiye et al. [42] prepared Co-CoOx-FeNiCo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for the selective hydrodeoxygenation of 5-HMF to DMF, which achieved a DMF yield ∼99.9 % in THF at 190 °C, 2.0 MPa H2 pressure, reaction time of 4 h with a catalyst addition of 40 % substrate. Schüth et al. [30] developed a Pt-Co bimetallic nanoparticle supported on hollow carbon spheres (PtCo@HCS) catalyst that demonstrated remarkable performance with a high DMF yield reaching up to 98 % in butanol solvent at 180 °C, 1.0 MPa H2 pressure for 2 h with a catalysts-to-substrate ratio of 20 %. Despite significant progress has been made towards the selective hydrodeoxygenation of 5-HMF to DMF, it is worth noting that achieving high conversion for 5-HMF as well as superior selectivity towards DMF often requires employing noble metal-based catalysts or large quantities of non-noble metal catalysts along with prolonged reaction times at higher temperatures and pressures; consequently, resulting in lower space-time productivity for the target product - DMF. Therefore, there remains an urgent need to develop highly efficient catalytic systems possessing simpler compositions and enhanced activity under milder reaction conditions. On the other hand, despite the speculation and proposals of various potential mechanisms, there remains a scarcity of experimental studies investigating the adsorption and reaction mechanism of 5-HMF hydrodeoxygenation to DMF. This limitation hinders a comprehensive understanding of the catalyst's active sites in this reaction. Therefore, it is imperative to employ experimental methods for studying the reaction mechanism in order to facilitate accurate design of novel and highly efficient catalysts for 5-HMF hydrodeoxygenation to DMF. SBA-15 molecular sieve is widely used as a catalyst support due to its excellent mesoporous structure, which contributes to improving the accessibility of active sites and enhancing the mass transfer rate. In the present study, a series of xCo/SBA-15 catalysts with high specific surface area and abundant mesopores were synthesized. By adjusting the loading of Co, both the metallic Co and Lewis acidic Co2+ in dispersed CoO on the catalyst surface could be finely tuned, thereby enhancing the hydrogenation of aldehyde group and hydrogenolysis of alcoholic hydroxyl group in 5-HMF. Consequently, high activity and selectivity for the mild hydrodeoxygenation of 5-HMF to DMF were achieved. Additionally, a solvent-switching strategy was employed successfully to selectively synthesize both 2,5-BHMF and 2,5-DMF. Furthermore, we investigated the adsorption and reaction mechanism of 5-HMF hydrodeoxygenation to DMF using programmed temperature surface reaction technology. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The following chemicals were purchased from Sinopharm Group (Shanghai, China): Co(NO3)2·6 H2O (98.5 %), THF (99.5 %), ethanol (99.5 %), isopropanol (99.7 %), and N,N-DMF (99.5 %). Aladdin (Shanghai, China) provided 1-butanol (99 %), γ-butyrolactone (GBL, 99 %), dodecane (98 %), DMF (99 %), BHMF (99 %), 5-methylfurfural (5-MF, 98 %) and 5-methylfurfuryl alcohol (MFA, 99 %). J&K Scientific supplied the chemical compound of 5-HMF (98 %). SBA-15 and MCM-41 were purchased from XFNANO (Nanjing). 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Co3O4 was synthesized through the pyrolysis of Co(NO3)2·6 H2O in a static air at 500 °C for 4 h. This resulting sample was designated as Co3O4. The reduced Co3O4 at 400 °C for 2 h under flowing H2 was denoted Co3O4-400. The SBA-15 supported Co catalysts were prepared using the impregnation method. Specifically, 0.5 g of SBA-15 and 0.9877 g of Co(NO3)2·6 H2O were dispersed in 10 ml deionized water and sonicated for 1 h. The mixture was then stirred for 6 h under oil bath heating at 60 °C, dried for 12 h at 80 °C in oven, and finally calcined in a static air at 500 °C for 4 h. The synthesized black powder catalyst denoted as 25Co/SBA-15. The xCo/SBA-15 catalysts (x = 15, 20 and 30 wt%) with different Co loading were also prepared using the same procedure. Additionally, by following the same procedure mentioned above but replacing SBA-15 with MCM-41, we also synthesized the 25Co/MCM-41 catalyst. 2.3 Characterizations The catalyst texture properties were determined using an ASAP 2020 PLUS HD88 specific surface area analyzer. The catalysts were degassed under vacuum at 350 °C for 6 h and then subjected to N2 isothermal adsorption and desorption at −196 °C. Wide-angle XRD patterns were obtained using a powder X-ray diffractometer (D8 Advance) with a Cu target (λ = 0.15418 nm) as the X-ray source, scanning over a range of 10–80° with a step size of 0.02° and a dwell time of 0.2 s. For fine scanning to calculate the average size of Co and CoO, the dwell time was increased to 1 s. Small-angle XRD patterns were obtained within a range of 0.5–3° with a dwell time of 1 s. The reduced samples were protected against oxidation with paraffin before XRD analysis. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using a Kratos Axis Ultra electron spectrometer with an Al Kα radiation. The ex-situ reduced samples were transferred to the testing chamber under the protection of high-purity nitrogen. Calibration was performed relative to the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. The Co content in the catalysts was quantified using an Agilent 700 ICP-OES spectrometer. The morphology of the catalysts was observed using a Hitachi SU8220 field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM). Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images, and energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping were acquired on a JEM-2100F equipped with an EDS energy spectrometer for further analysis on elemental composition and structure. The fresh and used catalysts were subjected to thermogravimetric analysis (TG) using a TA-Q600SDT Thermogravimetric Analyzer, with a ramp rate of 10 °C·min−1 and an air flow of 100 ml·min−1, in the temperature range from 30 to 800 °C. The NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), and temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) of 5-HMF and H2 were conducted using an AutoChem II 2920 instrument (Micromeritics, USA) coupled with a mass spectrometry detector (Hiden-20, UK). For the H2-TPR experiments, 50 mg of catalyst in a U-type quartz tube was heated to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C·min−1 under a flowing atmosphere of 10 % H2/Ar. For the NH3-TPD tests, after reduction, 50 mg of catalyst was pretreated in a U-quartz tube at 150 °C for 1 h under a flowing He atmosphere. It was then naturally cooled down to 100 °C. Subsequently, the catalyst was saturated with adsorbed NH3 at 100 °C for 1 h and purged with He for 30 min to remove physically adsorbed NH3. Finally, the catalyst was heated to 800 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C·min−1. The TPSR procedure followed previous reports [11]. For the TPSR-5-HMF-H2 process, 50 mg of reduced catalyst was loaded in a quartz tube reactor and heated to 80 °C. 5-HMF in the vapor generator was introduced onto the catalyst surface via 25 pulses before being purged with He for 30 min. Subsequently, the catalyst was saturated with 10 % H2 for 30 min followed by purging with He again for 30 min, and then was heated to 500 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C·min−1. The mass signals corresponding to H2, 5-HMF, BHMF, MFA, and DMF were recorded during the TPSR process. While for the TPSR-H2-5-HMF process, H2 was firstly introduced, followed by 5-HMF. 2.4 Catalytic performance evaluation The catalytic performance evaluation of the synthesized catalysts was conducted in a YZPR-50 hydrogenation reactor (Shanghai Yanzheng Experimental Instrument Co., Ltd.). Prior to usage, all the as-prepared catalysts were reduced at 400 °C for 2 h under flowing H2 in a tube furnace with a ramp rate of 5 °C·min−1. Typically, 0.1 g of 5-HMF, 20 mg of catalyst, and 20 ml of solvent were sealed in a 50 ml batch reactor after being purged with N2 to eliminate air. Subsequently, the reactor was pressurized with H2 to 2 MPa and heated to 150 °C at a stirring speed of 500 rpms. The quantitative analysis of hydrogenation products derived from the conversion of 5-HMF was performed using an Agilent 6820 A gas chromatograph equipped with an HP-5 capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.5 µm) and a flame ionization detector using dodecane as an internal standard. The conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural was determined by employing the following equation: X 5 − HMF % = moles of converted 5 − HMF moles of initial 5 − HMF × 100 The yields (Yi) of the hydrogenation products e.g. BHMF, MFA, and DMF were calculated according to the following equation, respectively. Y i % = moles of product i moles of initial 5 − HMF × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of the catalysts Table 1 shows the compositions and structural properties of these catalysts. The Co content in the catalysts was similar to the set values, indicating that Co3O4 was well deposited on the surface of the supports. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of the synthesized catalysts are presented in Fig. S1a. All the curves exhibited type IV isothermal adsorption behavior with a type H1 hysteresis loop. An evident saturated adsorption plateau can be observed in the adsorption-desorption curves, indicating a homogeneous distribution of mesoporous structure within the samples [43]. The pore size distribution (Fig. S1b) revealed similar distributions for all SBA-15 supported catalysts, ranging from 6 to 8 nm. While, the MCM-41 supported Co catalyst had a smaller average pore diameter, ranging from 2 to 3 nm. The SBA-15 sample had a high BET specific surface area of 1465 m2·g−1 and a pore volume of 2.67 cm3·g−1. Incorporation of cobalt significantly altered the textural properties of SBA-15, leading to a remarkably reduction in specific surface area and pore volume to 422 m2·g−1 and 0.96 cm3·g−1 for 25Co/SBA-15, respectively, accompanied by an increase in average pore size from 6.6 to 8.6 nm. This phenomenon can be attributed to the dilution effect caused by Co addition and the blocking of some pores of SBA-15 by Co deposition. The MCM-41 sample had a high BET specific surface area of 1133 m2·g−1, a pore volume of 2.67 cm3·g−1 and an average pore diameter of 2.9 nm. After loading Co, the specific surface area and pore volume were reduced to 615 m2·g−1 and 0.54 cm3·g−1, respectively. However, the mean diameter of the pore was little changed at 2.9 nm. The wide-angle XRD patterns ( Fig. 1a) of the Co3O4 sample exhibited six characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 19.0° (1 1 1), 31.3° (2 2 0), 36.8° (3 1 1), 44.8° (4 0 0), 59.4° (5 1 1), and 65.2° (4 4 0). These peaks can be attributed to the cubic phase of Co3O4. The average particle size of the as-prepared Co3O4 was determined to be 22.4 nm. In contrast, for the supported Co catalysts, due to effective dispersion on SBA-15 and MCM-41 surfaces, the intensity of Co3O4 diffraction peaks in these catalysts was significantly reduced. Comparatively, the average particle sizes of Co3O4 in xCo/SBA-15 samples ranged from 9.9 to 12.2 nm; whereas in 25Co/MCM-41 sample, it was found to be 5.5 nm. This observation suggests that MCM-41 provides a better dispersing for Co3O4. The small-angle XRD pattern (Fig. S2a) of the SBA-15 sample exhibited a distinct diffraction peak at approximately 0.79°, corresponding to the (1 0 0) crystal faces of a two-dimensional hexagonal structure, thereby confirming the typical ordered mesoporous nature of SBA-15 [11]. All the xCo/SBA-15 catalysts displayed similar diffraction peaks around 0.8°, indicating that even after cobalt impregnation, SBA-15 maintained its original regular hexagonal mesostructure. Both MCM-41 and 25Co/MCM-41 exhibited similar diffraction peaks at around 0.87°, which confirmed that 25Co/MCM-41 had a hexagonal ordered mesoporous structure similar to that of MCM-41. The subsequent reduction of Co3O4 using H2 at 400 °C led to a structural transition from Co3O4 to metallic Co and amorphous CoO phases, as confirmed by the corresponding XRD pattern in Fig. 1b and the subsequent XPS analysis. The peaks at 2θ values of 41.7°, 44.7°, 47.5° and 75.9° were attributed to the (1 0 0), (0 0 2), (1 0 1) and (1 1 0) reflections of hexagonal close-packed metallic Co (ICDD No. 97–004–4990), respectively. It is worth mentioning that agglomeration phenomenon occurred in the reduced Co3O4-400 sample, resulting in the formation of larger metallic Co particles (26.0 nm). The XRD patterns of xCo/SBA-15 catalyst shown in Fig. 1b exhibited distinctive diffraction peaks, confirming the reduction of Co3O4 to metallic Co and CoO on the supported catalyst. The weak peak at a 2θ value of 44.2° could be attributed to the (1 1 1) reflection of face-centered cubic metallic Co (ICDD No. 97–004–4989). While the peaks at 2θ values of 36.5°, 42.4° and 61.5° were attributed to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0) and (2 2 0) reflections of CoO (ICDD No. 97–000–9865). To determine the average sizes of the Co and CoO particles, the reduced samples were finely scanned in the 2θ range from 38° to 48° with a 2θ step size of 0.02° and a dwell time of 1 s. The detailed XRD patterns are shown in Fig. S2b, and the corresponding average grain sizes of metallic Co and CoO are listed in Table 1. The size of metallic Co estimated using Scherrer’s equation was between 14 and 17 nm; whereas the size of CoO ranged from 5.2 to 8.5 nm for the reduced xCo/SBA-15 catalysts. The 25Co/MCM41 catalyst exhibited smaller grain sizes for both metallic Co which was approximately ∼12.1 nm, and CoO which was around 4.7 nm, respectively. The surface morphology and structure of the representative 25Co/SBA-15 catalyst were analyzed using SEM and TEM, as depicted in Fig. 2. The SEM image revealed that 25Co/SBA-15 consisted of rod-like particles resembling typical SBA-15 structures, along with cloud-like particles attributed to Co species deposition. TEM analysis (Fig. 2b) demonstrated the presence of ordered two-dimensional hexagonal mesoporous channels within the SBA-15 molecular sieve. Following Co species deposition, small particles became prominently visible within both the pore channels and outer surface of SBA-15. High-resolution TEM images (Fig. 2c-d) displayed lattice fringes corresponding to metallic Co (1 1 1) crystal face at a spacing of 0.2001 nm, as well as CoO (2 0 0) crystal face at a spacing of 0.2125 nm respectively. STEM imaging and EDS-mapping results for 25Co/SBA-15 are presented in Fig. 2e-f, revealing even distribution of Co, Si, and O elements throughout the sample, indicating successful dispersion of Co species on the support surface. The reduction behavior of Co species was analyzed using the H2-TPR technique, and the results are presented in Fig. 3. The reduction curve of bulk Co3O4 exhibited two dominant reduction peaks below 450 °C. The first small peak at 340 °C corresponds to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, while the second large peak centered at 400 °C corresponds to the reduction of Co2+ to metallic Co [22,23]. 15Co/SBA-15 displayed a reduction peak at 320 °C and a shoulder peak at 350 °C, with a long tail extending up to 800 °C. The reduction peak at 320 °C can be attributed to the conversion from Co3+ to Co2+, while the tailing peak in the high temperature range is ascribed to the transformation from Co2+ to metallic Co. These results indicate that smaller particle size and higher dispersion lead to a decrease in initial reduction temperature for converting Co3+ to Co2+, whereas reducing Co2+ to Co0 becomes significantly more challenging due to strong interactions between CoO and the support material. With increasing loading of Co, there was gradual enhancement in both area and intensity of the reduction peaks, particularly in higher temperature regions. For instance, when comparing with 25Co/SBA-15, 25Co/MCM-41 exhibited similar shapes for their respective reduction peaks; however, there was relatively smaller area under these peaks within middle temperature region (400–550 °C), while an evident increase was observed for a distinct peak occurring at 775 °C. The observed discrepancy can be attributed to the hindered reducibility of CoO particles confined within narrow pores, owing to stronger geometric interaction with the MCM-41 support. Table S2 presents the quantitative analysis of the reduction degree of various catalysts by TPR. Below 450 °C, Co3O4 can be fully reduced to metallic Co. For the supported Co catalysts, below 450 °C, all Co3+ were reduced to Co2+, and part of the Co2+ was further reduced to Co0. Moreover, the percentage of Co0 decreased as the Co loading amount increased, indicating enhanced interaction between CoO and the support. Below 450 °C, the reduction degree of Co2+-Co0 in 25Co/MCM-41 was lower than that in 25Co/SBA-15, which further confirms that there was a stronger geometric interaction between the Co species and the MCM-41 support. The XPS analysis was conducted to determine the elemental composition and chemical state on the catalyst surface. Fig. S3 illustrates the survey scan, Si 2p, and O 1 s profiles of the reduced catalysts, revealing the presence of four elements (Co, Si, O, and C) on the supported Co catalysts' surface. The O element originates from silica and cobalt oxides, while C is primarily attributed to surface-contaminated carbon. Fig. S4 presents Co 2p profiles of Co3O4 and Co3O4-400, with Table S1 listing the elemental binding energy data. The Co 2p3/2 profile of Co3O4-400 exhibited distinct peaks corresponding to metallic Co, Co2+, and satellite peak of Co2+ at binding energies of 778.2, 781.1, and 786.6 eV respectively [41]. No peaks at 779.7 or 790.0 eV that could be assigned to either Co3+ or its satellite peaks were observed, confirming complete reduction of Co3+ in Co3O4. As shown in Fig. 4, the deconvolution analysis reveals three distinct peaks located at 778.6, 781.2, and 786.6 eV for the reduced 15Co/SBA-5 catalyst's Co 2p3/2 profile, respectively. These peaks correspond to Co0, Co2+, and the satellite peak of Co2+. The binding energy of Co species in the xCo/SBA-15 catalysts exhibited an initial increase followed by a decrease, as depicted in Table 2 and Fig. 4. Notably, the highest binding energy was observed for Co0 (779.0 eV) and Co2+ (781.7 eV) species in the 25Co/SBA-15 catalyst, indicating a pronounced electronic interaction between Co species and the support material. The higher binding energies observed for Co0 and Co2+ in the xCo/SBA-15 catalysts compared to those in Co3O4-400 suggest electron deficiency within both the metallic Co and Co2+. The presence of the electron-deficient Co0 species would enhance the activation of H2 and facilitate the cleavage of H-H bonds due to its pronounced electrophilicity [35]. Meanwhile, the electron-deficient Co2+ might lead to an increase in Lewis acidity. In comparison with pure SBA-15, the decreasing trend in Si 2p binding energy within the xCo/SBA-15 catalysts further confirm charge transfer from the Co species to Si, highlighting a robust electronic interaction between the Co species and SBA-15 [44,45]. Variations were observed among the SBA-15 supported Co catalysts regarding charge transfer from the Co2+ species to Si, resulting in a significant increase in acid sites as confirmed by NH3-TPD analysis discussed subsequently. Compared with 25Co/SBA-15, a smaller chemical shift (∼0.1 eV) was observed for the binding energy of Co2+ (781.2 eV) in 25Co/MCM-41, indicating a weaker electronic interaction between the Co species and MCM-41 support. The acidity of these Co-based catalysts was investigated using NH3-TPD-MS. As depicted in Fig. 5, no desorption peak of NH3 was observed for SBA-15 and Co3O4-400, indicating the absence of acid sites in these two samples. All the supported Co catalysts exhibited weak (< 200 °C) and moderate (200–400 °C) acid sites. However, a predominance of moderate acid sites was observed in these catalysts as presented in Table S3. The significant increase in the number of acid sites on xCo/SBA-15 can be attributed to the high dispersion of CoO species on the surface of SBA-15 due to its strong electrophilicity. The interfacial Lewis acidity of CoOx has been reported to enhance the adsorption and activation of 5-HMF [42,44,46], thereby facilitating the hydrodeoxygenation process for converting 5-HMF into DMF. Among all catalysts, 25Co/SBA-15 demonstrated the highest number and strongest acidity of acidic sites due to an enhanced interaction between the Co species and SBA-15 on the catalyst surface, as confirmed by XPS analysis. Compared with 25Co/SBA-15, although 25Co/MCM-41 had a similar cobalt content and a higher dispersion of cobalt species, the number of its surface acid sites was significantly lower than that of 25Co/SBA-15. This may be due to the weaker electronic interaction between the Co2+ species and the support within the 25Co/MCM-41 catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic performance towards selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF The catalytic performance of these Co-based catalysts in the 5-HMF hydrogenation reaction is presented in Table 3. No conversion of 5-HMF was observed in the presence of SBA-15. However, complete conversion of 5-HMF was achieved by Co3O4-400, with yields of DMF, BHMF and MFA at 40.7 %, 18.2 % and 31.4 %, respectively. Previous studies have reported two possible reaction pathways for the tandem hydrodeoxygenation of 5-HMF to DMF [8,19,47] as shown in Scheme 1. In Pathway 1, BHMF is formed as the primary product through hydrogenation of the formyl group (-CHO) in 5-HMF to -CH2OH, followed by subsequent hydrodeoxygenation reactions leading to MFA and finally DMF formation. In Pathway 2, hydrodeoxygenation converts 5-HMF into 5-methylfurfural (5-MF), which is then hydrogenated to MFA before undergoing further hydrodeoxygenation steps resulting in DMF production. It has been previously reported that noble metal catalysts such as Pd or Ru predominantly follow Pathway 2 (via 5-MF) during HMF hydrogenation [15,16]. However, our results indicate that when using Co3O4-400 as a catalyst for converting 5-HMF, only BHMF, MFA and DMF were detected without any trace of 5-MF formation. Therefore, it can be concluded that on Co-based catalysts like Co3O4-400 used in this study primarily favor Pathway 1 during the hydrodeoxygenation reaction process; consistent with previous research findings [41,42]. The complete conversion of 5-HMF, albeit with a low yield of DMF over Co3O4-400, highlights its commendable hydrogenation performance while showcasing limited ability in the hydrogenolysis of -CH2-OH groups. When 15Co/SBA-15 was employed as a substitute for the Co3O4-400 catalyst, the yield of DMF in the product increased to 63.6 %, while the yield of MFA decreased to 21.7 % and no BHMF was detected. With an increase in the loading of Co content on SBA-15, there was a further enhancement in the yield of DMF in the product, accompanied by a further decrease in the yield of MFA. These results indicate that xCo/SBA-15 facilitates both hydrodeoxygenation reactions from BHMF to MFA and from MFA to DMF, which can be attributed to variations in acid site density influencing hydrodeoxygenation from BHMF to MFA and DMF. Moreover, it suggests that hydrodeoxygenation from MFA to DMF is rate-determining step for converting 5-HMF into DMF within this catalytic system. By employing 25Co/SBA-15, we achieved the highest yield of DMF at 96.3 %, likely due to its superior acid strength and larger number of acid sites promoting hydrodeoxygenation reactions from BHMF to MFA and MFA to DMF. On contrary, although complete conversion of 5-HMF was observed with 25Co/MCM-41 catalysts, only limited yields were obtained: 16.3 % for DMF, 27.1 % for BHMF, and 25.6 % for MFA. The lower yield of DMF can be attributed to the small number of acidic sites, the lower reduction degree of Cobalt and the narrow pore sizes in the 25Co/MCM-41 catalyst, which restrict the diffusion and conversion of reactant and intermediate molecules. 3.3 Optimization of the reaction conditions The impact of various reaction conditions on the hydrogenation of 5-HMF was investigated using the highly efficient catalyst 25Co/SBA-15, and the results are depicted in Fig. 6. Complete conversion of 5-HMF was achieved in all experiments. At a reaction temperature of 130 °C, the yield of DMF was found to be 69.5 %, while MFA accounted for 9.3 % and unidentified products constituted 21.1 %. The maximum DMF yield of 96.3 % was attained at a temperature of 150 °C. With further elevation of reaction temperature, the DMF yield gradually decreased due to potential undesired side reactions such as condensation of DMF or 5-HMF [37,48]. At an initial hydrogen pressure of 0.5 MPa, the product yielded 28.9 % MFA and 35.9 % DMF. Increasing the H2 pressure gradually enhanced the yield of DMF by promoting the concentration of dissolved H2 in the liquid phase, facilitating hydrogenation of 5-HMF and reaction intermediates. The maximum DMF yield achieved was 96.3 % under a pressure of 2.0 MPa H2. It is important to note that excessive H2 pressures (≥ 2.5 MPa) may inhibit the adsorption of 5-HMF at the CoO sites, thereby suppressing the formation of DMF. Therefore, for subsequent studies, a reaction temperature of 150 °C and a H2 pressure of 2.0 MPa were employed. The potential reaction intermediates were investigated by examining the impact of reaction time on the hydrogenation of 5-HMF. As illustrated in Fig. 6c, only BHMF and MFA intermediates were detected in the reaction mixture, further confirming that the hydrodeoxygenation reaction of 5-HMF follows Path 1 in Scheme 1 on the Co/SBA-15 catalyst. At the timing zero point, complete conversion of 5-HMF resulted in a yield of 34.6 % BHMF, 32.1 % MFA, and 10.7 % DMF. Upon extending the reaction time to 0.5 h, the yield of BHMF decreased to 19.8 %, while the yield of MFA increased to 41.1 %, and DMF increased to 20.9 %. These results indicate that BHMF formation through hydrogenation of 5-HMF was faster than MFA generation through hydrodeoxygenation from BHMF; meanwhile, DMF generation via hydrodeoxygenation from MFA was found to be the slowest step. These findings highlight that hydrodeoxygenation reactions involving BHMF and MFA intermediates play a crucial role during the hydrogenation process under investigation here. When extending the reaction time from 0 to 2 h, there was an increase in yield for producing DMF from 11 % to 96.3 %. However, further prolonging the reaction time led to a decrease in DMF yield due to side reactions. The reaction at high substrate concentration plays a crucial role in the economic viability of industrial processes, as it can significantly reduce the cost associated with subsequent separation procedures. As depicted in Fig. 6d, an increase in reactant concentration from 5 to 10 mg·ml−1 led to a decline in DMF yield from 96.3 % to 88.2 %. Further augmentation of the 5-HMF concentration resulted in the formation of intermediate products such as 2,5-BHMF, MFA, and unidentified byproducts, indicating insufficient catalyst availability for complete hydrogenation into DMF and enhanced occurrence of side reactions due to facile hydroxy aldol addition/condensation of α, β-unsaturated aldehyde (i.e., 5-HMF) leading to humins formation. The selection of solvents in biomass upgrading plays a pivotal role in determining the selectivity and reaction pathway of the final product. Solvents can modify the adsorption state of the active site towards the substrate, influence the stability of intermediates, or serve as co-catalysts by promoting effective transfer of protons and electrons [49,50]. In this study, complete conversion of 5-HMF was achieved over the 25Co/SBA-15 catalyst with significant variations in product distribution when employing six different solvents: THF, ethanol, IPA, 1-butanol, N,N-DMF, and GBL as depicted in Fig. 7. When THF was utilized as the solvent, DMF yield reached up to 96.3 %. Employing N,N-DMF as the solvent resulted in a remarkable yield of 2,5-BHMF at around 90 %. Furthermore, utilizing GBL as the solvent led to a more than 75 % yield of 2,5-BHMF. These findings suggest that N, N-DMF, and GBL exhibit the ability to stabilize BHMF intermediates and inhibit hydrogenolysis reactions of BHMF towards MFA and DMF formation. However, further investigation is required to elucidate the underlying mechanisms. However, when IPA was employed as the solvent a moderate DMF yield of 75.3 % was obtained. Similarly, low DMF yields were obtained when using ethanol (37.5 %) or butanol (70 %) as solvents for hydrogenation reactions involving these alcohols; moreover, substantial amounts of undetectable products were observed under these conditions. This can be attributed to the adsorption configuration of 5-HMF in alcohol solvents that could activate aldehyde groups and certain furan rings, thereby promoting C-O cracking [49], leading to side reactions. Importantly, utilizing two distinct solvents: N,N-DMF resulting in a high yield of 90 % for the production of BHMF, and THF yielding an higher yield of 96.3 % for DMF generation makes it feasible to switch between these two products during hydrogenation over the Co/SBA-15 catalyst. Based on the aforementioned results, the optimal reaction conditions for catalytic hydrogenation of 5-HMF over 25Co/SBA-15 are as follows: 0.1 g of 5-HMF, 20 ml of THF, 0.02 g of catalyst, at a temperature of 150 °C and a H2 pressure of 2 MPa with a reaction time of 2 h. Under these specific conditions, an impressive DMF yield of 96.3 % was achieved along with a corresponding productivity rate of DMF at 19.1 mmol·gcat−1·h−1. Furthermore, when the feed amount for the initial reactant (5-HMF) was increased to 0.2 g, an even higher productivity rate for DMF at approximately 35 mmol·gcat−1·h−1 was obtained. Notably, the catalytic performance exhibited by 25Co/SBA-15 in the hydrodeoxygenation from 5-HMF to DMF under mild reaction conditions is exceptionally superior compared to most previously reported catalysts in literature as shown in Table S4. 3.4 Catalyst recyclability The reusability of the 25Co/SBA-15 catalyst for the conversion of 5-HMF to DMF was evaluated using a higher concentration of 5-HMF (10 mg·ml−1). After each run, the used catalyst was recovered by centrifugation, washed with THF, and vacuum dried at 50 °C for 12 h before the next trial. As shown in Fig. 8, complete conversion of 5-HMF was achieved in all cycles; however, the yield of DMF decreased from an initial value of 88–72 % after four runs. TG analysis conducted on both fresh and used catalysts (Fig. S5a) revealed carbon deposits on the used catalyst surface, resulting in significant weight loss between temperatures ranging from 200 to 500 °C. Consequently, after the fourth cycle, calcination at a temperature of 400 °C for 1 h under a flowing air stream (20 ml·min−1) was performed to eliminate surface carbon deposits. Subsequently, reduction at a temperature of 400 °C for 2 h under a H2 atmosphere preceded its utilization in subsequent reactions. Following regeneration through this process, an improved yield up to 86 % for producing DMF was obtained. These findings demonstrate that convenient regeneration can be achieved by calcining the 25Co/SBA-15 catalyst at 400 °C under flowing air to remove carbon deposits. The used and regenerated 25Co/SBA-15 catalysts were further characterized to analyze the changes in catalyst structure. Carbon deposits were observed on the catalyst surface after use, as indicated by its highest C-to-Si ratio (Table S5), which is consistent with TG analysis. XRD patterns of the catalysts after use and regeneration showed no alterations in the Co phase. The predominant forms of Co species were metallic Co and CoO. However, XPS analysis (Fig. S5c and Table S5) revealed an increased content of metallic Co after use, indicating a deeper reduction of the catalyst under high-pressure hydrogen during the reaction. This phenomenon could be another reason for the observed decline in catalyst activity throughout the cycling process. Although the content of metallic Co in the regenerated catalyst was similar to that of the fresh catalyst, there was a slight decrease in the ratio of Co to Si, which may result in slight performance differences between them. 3.5 Reaction mechanism TPSR-H2-HMF and TPSR-HMF-H2 experiments were conducted to gain further insights into the interaction between reactant molecules and catalyst active sites during the reaction. Fig. 9a-b illustrates the desorption behavior of partially adsorbed H2 and 5-HMF from the surface of the 25Co/SBA-15 catalyst during the TPSR process. Notably, altering the adsorption sequence between H2 and 5-HMF resulted in distinct variations in desorption curves. The TPSR-H2-HMF process exhibited a continuous desorption of H2 above 175 °C, as depicted in Fig. 9a. A distinct desorption peak emerged at 375 °C with increasing temperature, while a significant desorption of H2 was observed above 500 °C. These results indicate that the surface of the 25Co/SBA-15 catalyst contained various hydrogen species with different adsorption strengths. Below 400 °C, the desorbed H2 can be attributed to hydrogen species adsorbed on the metallic Co surface, whereas H2 desorption above 400 °C can be attributed to spillover hydrogen onto the support surface [51]. Additionally, apart from H2 desorption, a minor quantity of 5-HMF was also released starting from 250 °C and reached its maximum temperature at 340 °C. During this process, small quantities of BHMF and MFA intermediates were observed during desorption; however, no DMF was detected. The presence of these minute quantities of desorbed 5-HMF may potentially originate from adsorbed 5-HMF onto isolated CoO sites. The findings suggest that there is insufficient activated hydrogen surrounding isolated CoO active sites for the conversion of adsorbed 5-HMF on isolated CoO sites into DMF. In the case of TPSR-HMF-H2, preferential adsorption of 5-HMF on the catalyst surface led to desorption products containing a significant amount of 5-HMF from 150 to 370 °C. Desorption of a small quantity of H2 occurred from 175 to 420 °C. The product also exhibited moderate desorption of DMF in the temperature range of 150–370 °C, along with substantial desorption of MFA intermediates within the same temperature range. Notably, no BHMF desorption was observed in the product, indicating rapid conversion of BHMF to MFA on the 25Co/SBA-15 catalyst while exhibiting relatively slow conversion rate from MFA to DMF. These findings suggest that 5-HMF may undergo adsorption and activation at CoO active sites adjacent to metallic Co sites, followed by reaction with dissociated and activated hydrogen species at these metallic Co sites resulting in formation of BHMF, MFA, and DMF. Based on the current experimental results and previous research [28,42,46,52], we propose a rational mechanism for the hydrogenation of 5-HMF as shown in Scheme 2. The hydrogenation of 5-HMF over the 25Co/SBA-15 catalyst follows a dual-site Langmuir–Hinshelwood–Hougen–Watson (LHHW) model. Initially, the electroaffinity of CoO allows for the adsorption and activation of the CO group in 5-HMF on its Lewis acidic Co2+ site, while neighboring metallic Co adsorbs and cleaves H2 into reactive H species. The proximity between Co and CoO enables a reaction between these reactive H species and activated CO groups, leading to the formation of BHMF. Subsequently, vertically adsorbed BHMF molecules on the surface of CoO via oxygen atoms from -CH2-OH groups at one end undergo further hydrogenolysis with reactive hydrogen species provided by metal Co to generate both MFA and H2O. Finally, Lewis acidic Co2+ in CoO can adsorb and activate the hydroxyl group in MFA molecules, which is then further hydrogenated, resulting in the formation of DMF. In summary, both metal Co and adjacent Lewis acidic Co2+ in CoO play distinct roles in catalytic processes: while metal Co facilitates H2 cleavage, Lewis acidic Co2+ in CoO enhance adsorption and activation processes involving 5-HMF, BHMF, and MFA. 4 Conclusion The present study focuses on the synthesis of xCo/SBA-15 catalysts with a high specific surface area and abundant mesopores. By adjusting the Co loading, both metallic Co and Lewis acidic sites originating from dispersed CoO on the catalyst surface can be finely tuned, thereby enhancing the hydrogenation of aldehyde groups and hydrogenolysis of alcoholic hydroxyl groups in 5-HMF. As a result, we achieved high activity and selectivity for the hydrodeoxygenation of 5-HMF to DMF. Under optimal reaction conditions (150 °C, 2 MPa H2 for 2 h) with a catalyst-to-substrate ratio of 20 %, an impressive yield of 96.3 % for 2,5-DMF was obtained with a productivity of 19.1 mmol·gcat·h−1. Furthermore, when using THF or N,N-DMF solvents separately, our catalyst exhibited switchable selectivity towards either 2,5-DMF or 2,5-BHMF as products. Notably, our catalyst demonstrates excellent reusability and can be easily regenerated through calcination in air to remove carbon deposits. The exceptional catalytic performance can be attributed to the synergistic effect between metallic Co and adjacent Lewis acidic Co2+ in CoO where metallic Co facilitates H2 cleavage while Lewis acidic Co2+ enhance adsorption and activation processes involving 5-HMF, BHMF, and MFA. coredata.dc:description: The design of highly efficient and cost-effective catalysts for the conversion of biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) into sustainable liquid fuel 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) is both important and challenging. In this study, we developed a non-noble Co catalyst supported on SBA-15 (25Co/SBA-15). Our results demonstrate that this catalyst exhibits remarkable efficiency in selectively hydrodeoxygenating 5-HMF to DMF, achieving a DMF yield of 96.3 % with complete conversion of 5-HMF under mild reaction conditions (150 °C, 2.0 MPa H2 for 2 h). Notably, the productivity rate of DMF reached an exceptional value of 19.1 mmol·gcat−1·h−1, surpassing most previously reported catalysts in literature. Additionally, by utilizing two distinct solvents - N,N-dimethylformamide (N,N-DMF) resulting in a high yield of 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF) and tetrahydrofuran (THF) yielding an even higher yield of DMF - our approach enables facile switching between these two products during hydrogenation over the Co/SBA-15 catalyst. Furthermore, our catalyst demonstrates excellent reusability and can be easily regenerated through calcination in air. The exceptional catalytic performance of the catalyst can be ascribed to the synergistic effect between metallic Co and adjacent Lewis acidic Co2+ in CoO dispersed on the surface of SBA-15. A dual-site Langmuir–Hinshelwood–Hougen–Watson (LHHW) model was proposed for the hydrodeoxygenating 5-HMF to DMF.
